declarations.description:
`furo-config-loader` loads a configuration json in to the defined section.

To access the config values, use `furo-config`.

```html
<furo-config-loader
    src="/custom/view-config.json"
    section="views"
    ></furo-config-loader>
```
declarations.name: FuroConfigLoader

members.name: _FBPReady
members.description: flow is ready lifecycle method

members.name: src
members.description: File source

members.name: section
members.description: Targeted section to load the config in.

events.description: Fired when the config is loaded with the loaded config as detail.
events.name: config-loaded

attributes.name: src
attributes.description: File source

attributes.name: section
attributes.description: Targeted section to load the config in.

declarations.description:
`furo-config`

 Access config data


```html
<!-- set with config-loader -->
<furo-config-loader
    section="views"
    src="/viewconfig.json"
    ></furo-config>


<!-- consume a config -->
<furo-config
    section="views" at-config-updated="--conf"
    ></furo-config>

<!-- consume a sub path of a config section -->
<furo-config
    section="views.subset.deep" at-config-updated="--deepconf"
    ></furo-config>
```
declarations.name: FuroConfig

members.name: section
members.description:
section of the config object that you are interested in

access deep object with dots like `main.sub.sub`

members.name: config
members.description: The current section of the config, which was defined by `section`.

events.description: Fired when section changed
events.name: config-updated

attributes.name: section
attributes.description:
section of the config object that you are interested in

access deep object with dots like `main.sub.sub`

declarations.description:
The Debounce technique allow us to “group” multiple sequential calls in a single one.

[Read more about debouncing here](https://css-tricks.com/debouncing-throttling-explained-examples/)



```html
<furo-de-bounce
    fn-trigger="--searchStringEntered" at-debounced="--debouncedSrch"
    ></furo-de-bounce>
```
declarations.name: FuroDeBounce

members.name: _FBPReady
members.description: flow is ready lifecycle method

members.name: immediate
members.description:
If true, input-wire is triggered immediatley (leading edge instead of trailing)
Default value: false

members.name: wait
members.description:
Debounce time in milliseconds
Default value: 250

members.name: _createHandler
members.description: Internal create of debounce handler function

members.name: trigger

parameters.name: data
parameters.description: Any data, will be dispatched on the `debounced` event.

members.description: Trigger the debounce

members.name: inputWire
members.description: Debounce function

members.name: _debounce
members.description: as taken from Underscore.js

events.name: out
events.description: deprecated, use debounced instead. // TODO: remove @out and fn-input-wire in q2 2022

events.name: debounced
events.description: Fired after N milliseconds. If `immediate`is set to TRUE, it fires on the leading edge.

attributes.name: wait
attributes.description:
Debounce time in milliseconds
Default value: 250

attributes.name: immediate
attributes.description:
If true, input-wire is triggered immediatley (leading edge instead of trailing)
Default value: false

declarations.description:
`furo-feature-toggle`
 Is a handler for feature toggles, you can react to key changes with FBP.
 This component is quite simple, but gives you a lot of possibilities.
 Read more about feature toggles in the [guide](/docs/guides/featuretoggle/)

 ```html
 <!-- setting a key -->
<furo-feature-toggle
    key="feature.easter.egg" fn-set-true="--activateClicked" fn-set-false="--disableClicked">
    </furo-feature-toggle>

 <!-- observing key changes -->
 <furo-feature-toggle
    key="feature.xxxx.yyy"  at-key-activated="--fxyActivated" at-key-changed="--fxyChanged">
    </furo-feature-toggle>

 ```
declarations.name: FuroFeatureToggle

members.name: setFalse
members.description: Sets a feature key state to false.

members.name: setTrue
members.description: Sets a feature key state to true.

members.name: key
members.description: Name of a feature toggle.

events.name: key-true
events.description: Fired when the key is set to true or is true on init.

events.name: key-false
events.description: Fired when the key is set to false or is false on init.

events.name: key-changed
events.description: Fired on init and when the key changes its state.

attributes.name: key
attributes.description: Name of a feature toggle.

declarations.summary: flow based handler for feature toggles

declarations.name: FuroFetchJson

members.name: fetch
members.description:
fetch and parse the data from specified `src`.

Use fetch-src if you want to pass the source url

members.name: fetchSrc
members.description: fetch json data from source

members.name: src
members.description: the url you want to fetch

events.description: Fired when data received and json parsed
events.name: data

events.description: Fired when json is not parseable
events.name: parse-error

attributes.name: src
attributes.description: the url you want to fetch

declarations.description:
`furo-forth-stack` is a declarative stack, inspired by the forth stack.

https://hackaday.com/2017/01/27/forth-the-hackers-language/
http://wiki.laptop.org/go/Forth_stack_operators
http://galileo.phys.virginia.edu/classes/551.jvn.fall01/primer.htm#stacks
declarations.name: FuroForthStack

members.name: size
members.description: Current size of the stack

members.name: clearStack
members.description: Empties the stack and set the stack-size to 0

members.name: put
members.description: Add an element to the stack

members.name: swap
members.description:
swap **( n1 n2 -- n2 n1 )**

swap, as you may have guessed, swaps the top two elements of the stack. For example:

1 2 3 4 swap
will give you:

1 2 4 3 <- Top

members.name: drop
members.description:
drop **( n -- )**

 drop simply drops the top element of the stack. Running:

 1 2 3 drop
 gives you a stack of:

 1 2 <- Top

members.name: dup
members.description:
dup **( n -- n n )**

    dup is short for “duplicate” – it duplicates the top element of the stack. For example, try this out:

    1 2 3 dup

    You should end up with the following stack:

    1 2 3 3 <- Top

members.name: over
members.description:
over **( n1 n2 -- n1 n2 n1 )**

   over is a bit less obvious: it takes the second element from the top of the stack and duplicates it to the top of the stack. Running this:

   1 2 3 over
   will result in this:

   1 2 3 2 <- Top

members.name: rot
members.description:
rot **( n1 n2 n3 -- n2 n3 n1 )**

   Finally, rot “rotates” the top three elements of the stack. The third element from the top of the stack gets moved to the top of the stack, pushing the other two elements down.

   1 2 3 rot
   gives you:

   2 3 1 <- Top

members.name: rrot
members.description:
rrot **( n1 n2 n3 -- n3 n1 n2 )**

   Reverse rotation or right rotation rrot “rotates” the elements of the stack inverse to rot.
   The top elemen the stack gets moved to the bottom of the stack.

   1 2 3 rot
   gives you:

   3 1 2 <- Top

members.name: _move
members.description: moves element of an array from index to index*

members.name: _stack
members.description: The stack, should not be edited from outside

events.description: Fired when the stack size changes with Integer with the current size of the stack.
events.name: stack-size-changed

events.description: Fired when stack was rotated
events.name: rotated

events.description: Fired when the stack contents changes after put, drop,...
events.name: stack-changed

events.description: Fired when stack was swapped
events.name: swapped

events.description: Fired when stack gets empty
events.name: empty

declarations.description:
`furo-head-tail`
 Splits an iterable (i.e. Array) in its head and tail part.

```
 <furo-head-tail fn-split="--arrayData" at-head="--firstElement" at-tail="--restOfArray"></furo-head-tail>
```
declarations.name: FuroHeadTail

members.name: split
members.description:
Splits an iterable to its head (first item) and its tail (the rest) parts.

```
["a", "b", "c", "d"]
 |_|  |___________|
  ^      ^
  |      |
  |     TAIL   => ["b", "c", "d"]
 HEAD          => "a"
```

events.description: Fired when Array was splitted, contains the first element of array.
events.name: head

events.description: Fired when Array was splitted. {Array || Any} is the tail from the injected array (e1 - 1n)
events.name: tail

declarations.description:
`furo-key-filter`
Allows only defined keyboard events to pass through

```html
<!-- note the asterisk on other-component keydown. Because filter needs the keyboard event. -->
<other-component at-keydown="--keydown(*)"></other-component>
<furo-key-filter
    fn-filter="--keydown" at-matched="--escapePressed"
    keys="Escape"
    ></furo-key-filter>
```
declarations.name: FuroKeyFilter

members.name: filter
members.description: Check the event and dispatch matched when the conditions are fulfilled.

members.name: keys
members.description: Coma separated list with allowed keys to pass. i.e "Enter, ArrowUp"

members.name: shift
members.description: Modifier key **shift** must be pressed too to match

members.name: alt
members.description: Modifier key **alt** must be pressed too to match

members.name: command
members.description:
Alias for meta.

Modifier key **meta** must be pressed too to match.

members.name: meta
members.description: Modifier key **meta** must be pressed too to match

members.name: control
members.description: Modifier key **control** must be pressed too to match

events.description: Fired when key matches the options
events.name: matched

declarations.description:
`furo-keydown` attaches a keypress listener to the parent element and gives you handy events to work with.

When you set `alt`, `ctrl` or any of the other arguments, the key event will be triggered only if the corresponding key was pressed too.

 [more about keydown](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/keydown_event)

```html
<furo-keydown key="Enter" at-key="--enterPressed"></furo-keydown>
<furo-keydown ctrl key="c" at-key="--copyRequested"></furo-keydown>
```
declarations.name: FuroKeydown

members.name: _FBPReady
members.description: flow is ready lifecycle method

members.name: key
members.description: Key to listen on. Like Enter, Backspace, ArrowLeft, A,B,C, a,b,c

members.name: global
members.description: Set this attribute to listen to the keydown event global (window).

members.name: alt
members.description: `alt` key must be pressed to trigger the `key` event.

members.name: ctrl
members.description: `ctrl` key must be pressed to trigger the `key` event.

members.name: meta
members.description: `meta` key must be pressed to trigger the `key` event.

members.name: shift
members.description: `shift` key must be pressed to trigger the `key` event.

members.name: preventDefault
members.description: Set this attribute to prevent the event default of the keypress event.

members.name: stopPropagation
members.description: Set this to true to stop the event propagation of the keypress event.

events.description: Fired when key was catched on target

declarations.description:
`furo-navigation-pad` listens to different keyboard navigation events like the arrow keys. It will attach the listeners
 to the parent node and cancel the default and stop the propagation of the events.

 The events are available as standalone events or as combined event in the `navigated` event.

 ```html
 <!-- forward all navigation events except the Escape  -->
 <furo-navigation-pad
     ignored-keys="Escape" at-navigated="--navpad"
     ></furo-navigation-pad>

 ```
declarations.name: FuroNavigationPad

members.name: _FBPReady
members.description: flow is ready lifecycle method

members.name: ignoredKeys
members.description:
Enter the keys you want to ignore as comma seperated values.

i.e. "Escape, ArrowLeft"

events.description: Generic navigation event, fired when one of the navigation keys was pressed, detail contains one of these: Escape | Enter | ArrowDown | ArrowUp |ArrowLeft|ArrowRight| PageUp | PageDown | Home | End
events.name: navigated

events.description: Fired when Enter key was pressed.
events.name: enter-pressed

events.description: Fired when ArrowDown key was pressed.
events.name: arrow-down-pressed

events.description: Fired when ArrowUp key was pressed.
events.name: arrow-up-pressed

events.description: Fired when ArrowLeft key was pressed.
events.name: arrow-left-pressed

events.description: Fired when ArrowRight key was pressed.
events.name: arrow-right-pressed

events.description: Fired when Escape key was pressed.
events.name: escape-pressed

events.description: Fired when PageUp key was pressed.
events.name: page-up-pressed

events.description: Fired when PageDown key was pressed.
events.name: page-down-pressed

events.description: Fired when Home key was pressed.
events.name: home-pressed

events.description: Fired when End key was pressed.
events.name: end-pressed

Enter the keys you want to ignore as comma seperated values.

i.e. "Escape, ArrowLeft"
